snippet.title: Canberra lucky to still have Laurie Oakes as a local resident
snippet.content:
Laurie Oakes is truly one of nature's gentleman. The legend of Australian political reporting was inundated with wellwishes on Friday as news of his impending . But he still had time to answer a few questions about his attachment to Canberra, the city; not the byword for parliament.Photo: Laurie's last night on air for Channel Nine will be August 18. He confirmed to us that afterwards he had no plans to leave Canberra, a long-time resident of Red Hill. "I'll be staying in Canberra,' he said.Photo: Peter Morris "I like that it's within striking distance of Sydney and the coast and I think it's the most liveable city in Australia. "The facilities are good and when you get to my age, you do look at the health facilities.
"I know a lot of people retire to the coast but then they spend a lot of time on a bus coming back to Canberra to see a doctor.

"Canberra is a good place to live and a good place to retire."Photo: Andrew Meares The 73-year-old is expecting to spend at least part of his retirement "gently travelling around Australia". "See a bit more of the place and take it all very easy and relaxed," he said. Well-deserved, no doubt. And there was much goodwill for Oakes on Friday as the parliamentary press gallery prepared to lose one of its icons. "Twitter's been amazing. The papers' have been amazing. It's all been very overwhelming," he said. And while Oakes has dabbled in local planning issues as an ordinary Canberra citizen concerned about past housing proposals in Red Hill, he doesn't see himself writing furious letters-to-the-editor or becoming a local agitator in retirement. "I don't think so," he said, definitely.
